chapterMetadata.title: Quadratic Equations
chapterMetadata.subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Identify quadratic equations in the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a ≠ 0
Solve quadratic equations using factorization method
Analyze the nature of roots using the discriminant
Apply quadratic equations to solve real-life problems

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: An introduction to quadratic equations, their relevance in real-life situations, and a brief history of solving quadratic equations in various civilizations.

keyConcepts.name: Quadratic Equation
keyConcepts.description: An equation of the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, c are real numbers, and a ≠ 0

keyConcepts.name: Standard Form
keyConcepts.description: The form ax² + bx + c = 0 where terms are arranged in descending order of their degrees
properties: Coefficient of x² must be non-zero

visualElements.description: Rectangular hall with dimensions labeled, illustrating how the area constraint leads to a quadratic equation
visualElements.interactivityHint: Interactive model where students can adjust length and width to understand the relationship with area

examples.problem: A charity trust wants to build a prayer hall with carpet area of 300 square meters. The length is one meter more than twice its breadth. Find the dimensions of the hall.
examples.solution: Let the breadth be x meters. Then length = (2x + 1) meters. Area = length × breadth = (2x + 1)x = 2x² + x. Since area = 300, we get 2x² + x = 300, or 2x² + x - 300 = 0.

sections.title: Quadratic Equations
sections.summary: Formal definition of quadratic equations and identifying quadratic equations from various mathematical expressions.

keyConcepts.name: Roots of Quadratic Equation
keyConcepts.description: Values of the variable that satisfy the quadratic equation
properties: A quadratic equation can have at most two roots

examples.problem: John and Jivanti together have 45 marbles. Both lost 5 marbles each, and the product of the number of marbles they now have is 124. How many marbles did they have initially?
examples.solution: Let John have x marbles. Then Jivanti has (45-x) marbles. After losing 5 each, they have (x-5) and (40-x) marbles respectively. Given their product is 124, we get (x-5)(40-x) = 124, which gives x² - 45x + 324 = 0.

examples.problem: Check whether (x-2)² + 1 = 2x - 3 is a quadratic equation.
examples.solution: LHS = (x-2)² + 1 = x² - 4x + 4 + 1 = x² - 4x + 5. So the equation becomes x² - 4x + 5 = 2x - 3, which gives x² - 6x + 8 = 0. This is a quadratic equation.

sections.title: Solution of a Quadratic Equation by Factorisation
sections.summary: Solving quadratic equations by factorizing them into linear factors and using the zero-product property.

keyConcepts.name: Factorization Method
keyConcepts.description: Express the quadratic polynomial as a product of two linear factors and set each factor to zero
properties: Relies on finding the appropriate splitting of the middle term

keyConcepts.name: Zero-Product Property
keyConcepts.description: If a product of factors is zero, then at least one of the factors must be zero
properties: Fundamental property used to find roots after factorization

examples.problem: Find the roots of 2x² - 5x + 3 = 0 by factorisation.
examples.solution: 2x² - 5x + 3 = 2x² - 2x - 3x + 3 = 2x(x-1) - 3(x-1) = (2x-3)(x-1). Setting each factor to zero: 2x-3=0 gives x=3/2, and x-1=0 gives x=1. So the roots are 1 and 3/2.

examples.problem: Find the dimensions of a prayer hall with carpet area 300 square meters where length is one meter more than twice the breadth.
examples.solution: From 2x² + x - 300 = 0, we get 2x² - 24x + 25x - 300 = 0, which gives (x-12)(2x+25) = 0. Since breadth must be positive, x = 12 meters. Length = 2x+1 = 25 meters.

sections.title: Nature of Roots
sections.summary: Analyzing the nature of roots of a quadratic equation using the discriminant and the quadratic formula.

keyConcepts.name: Discriminant
keyConcepts.description: The expression b² - 4ac that determines the nature of roots of a quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0
properties: If b² - 4ac > 0, the equation has two distinct real roots
If b² - 4ac = 0, the equation has two equal real roots
If b² - 4ac < 0, the equation has no real roots

keyConcepts.name: Quadratic Formula
keyConcepts.description: Formula to find the roots of a quadratic equation directly
properties: Applicable to any quadratic equation in standard form

visualElements.description: Circular park with a pole at boundary, illustrating the application of quadratic equations to geometric problems
visualElements.interactivityHint: Interactive model showing how the position of the pole affects distances

examples.problem: Find the discriminant of 2x² - 4x + 3 = 0 and determine the nature of its roots.
examples.solution: Here a = 2, b = -4, c = 3. Discriminant = b² - 4ac = (-4)² - 4(2)(3) = 16 - 24 = -8 < 0. Since the discriminant is negative, the equation has no real roots.

examples.problem: A pole is erected at a point on the boundary of a circular park with diameter 13 meters. The difference in distances from the pole to two diametrically opposite gates A and B is 7 meters. Find the distances from the pole to the gates.
examples.solution: Using Pythagoras theorem and the given conditions, we arrive at the equation x² + 7x - 60 = 0. Using the quadratic formula, we get x = 5 or x = -12. Since distance can't be negative, the pole should be 5m from gate B and 12m from gate A.

theorems.statement: For a quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0, if the discriminant b² - 4ac = 0, then the equation has exactly one repeated root given by x = -b/2a
theorems.explanation: When the discriminant is zero, the quadratic formula gives the same value for both roots

keyVocabulary.definition: An equation of the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, c are real numbers and a ≠ 0
The values of the variable that satisfy the equation
The expression b² - 4ac that determines the nature of roots
The process of expressing a quadratic expression as a product of linear factors

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All expressions containing x² are quadratic equations
commonMisconceptions.correction: An equation is quadratic only if it can be written in the form ax² + bx + c = 0 with a ≠ 0

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Every quadratic equation has exactly two roots
commonMisconceptions.correction: A quadratic equation can have two distinct real roots, two equal real roots, or no real roots depending on the discriminant

commonMisconceptions.misconception: An equation that appears cubic may not be quadratic
commonMisconceptions.correction: Some equations that appear higher degree may simplify to quadratic equations after algebraic manipulations

assessmentIdeas.question: Find two numbers whose sum is 27 and product is 182.
assessmentIdeas.answer: Let the numbers be x and 27-x. Their product is x(27-x) = 182, which gives x² - 27x + 182 = 0. Solving this quadratic equation gives x = 13 or x = 14. So the numbers are 13 and 14.

assessmentIdeas.question: The altitude of a right triangle is 7 cm less than its base. If the hypotenuse is 13 cm, find the base and altitude.
assessmentIdeas.answer: Using Pythagoras theorem and the relationship between base and altitude, we get a quadratic equation whose solution gives base = 12 cm and altitude = 5 cm.

assessmentIdeas.question: Is it possible to design a rectangular mango grove whose length is twice its breadth, and the area is 800 m²?
assessmentIdeas.answer: Let breadth = x meters. Then length = 2x meters. Area = length × breadth = 2x² = 800, which gives x = 20. So it's possible with dimensions 20m × 40m.
